DIV1.P: A COMEDY, As it is Acted at the Queens Theatre in the Hay-Market.

LONDON: Printed for William Turner at the Angel at Lin∣colns-Inn Back-Gate, James Knapton at the Crown in St. Paul's Church-Yard, Bernard Lin∣tot in Fleetstreet, and B. Bragg at the Black Ra∣ven in Pater-Noster-Row. Price 1s. 6d.

DIV1.HEAD: To the Honourable Sr. JACOB BANKS.
DIV1.P: 'TIS very natural for Persons who attempt things of this Nature, to lay hold on the smallest Occasion to claim the Protection of the Generous and Just. I have heard you commend Spanish Stories, and having ventur'd upon one, pre∣sume to offer it at your Feet. It is almost im∣possible for a Man of your Goodness and Chara∣cter, to escape Addresses of this kind; for as the Sower and Morose despise the Muse, so she always flies them, a Clime too rough and tempestuous for her tender Pinions; but with Pleasure aspires to the Brave: And who more truly deserves that Epi∣thet, than Sr. Jacob Banks?

One, who tho' not born a Native of England, yet, by his Zeal for the Glory of the Best of Queens, and constant Assertion for the Nation's Cause has Justly made this Country his own, unshaken to his Friend, and delighting to do kind Offices to all. I am entred upon a Theme which did I follow my Inclinations, I should not easily quit; but sometimes even Truth of∣fends
in so nice a Point as Praise; and Persons of Merit with less Pain Do great Actions, than hear of them. That you may still possess all Happi∣ness, and long enjoy those Pledges of your Love left you by a Beauteous Wife, for whose Memory you retain such a Veneration and Tenderness, scarce to be met with in your Sex; that these, and all other Blessings may continually attend you, is the daily Wish of,
DIV1.CLOSER: SIR, Your most Humble, and most Obedient Servant,

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE
DIV1.L: TO hit your Tast we've try'd a thousand Ways
Pastorals, Opera's, and some good Plays:
A House was built, the Lord knows what the Charge,
We find indeed the Structure proves too large;
That, nor the Season, stops our Diligence,
We still play on, tho' at our own Expence.
And like some Miser who has done his Best,
To furnish out one various Splendid Feast,
To little Trifles he at last descends,
And with whipt Cream and Froth Regales his Friends;
So we in Farce a Summer Present bring,
For once accept the humble Offering.
Good Humour sure, must reign in every Breast,
Whilst thus with Victory our Arms are blest?
Whilst—
In the Field the British Trumpets sound,
And each returning Year is with new Conquests Crown'd,
Lewis grown Old in Falshood and Design,
Where Valour fail'd, supply'd his Force with Coin.
But our Great Chief upon the open Plain,
The Cause of injur'd Nations does maintain;
Snatches the Guilty Laurels France has worn,
Which justly now the Conqueror's Line adorn;
Who, like another Scipio leads us on,
And merits all the Wreaths the Romans Won.

LIST.HEAD: Men.
LIST.ITEM: Gomez a very old cross Lord,—Mr. Freeman.
Gaylove a young English Gentleman,—Mr. Booth.
Don Phillip Nephew to the Old Man—Mr. Cory.

LIST.HEAD: Women.
LIST.ITEM: Laura a Lady under Gomez care,—Mrs. Bracegirdle.
Lisset Friend to Laura and Clarin∣da who passes for an Eunuch,—Mrs. Bicknel.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. I. SCENE Madrid, The Embassadour's House.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Gay-love meeting Bellmour, Bellmour in a Spanish Habit.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: SAVE ye Don Bellmour as a Man may say, you are Equipt I see a la Mode D'Espagne. What canst thou mean by this—S'death I'd assoon change the Habit of thy Sex and wear the Womens Furbe∣lows as these Dam'd Golilia's.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Behold what a pair of Spectacles my Rogue of a Tay∣or has brought me, Sight of which I a great Passion bid him look in my Face and guess those Helps. Don Thimble with the Gravity of a Corrigidore answer'd, 'twas a Proof of Manhood not of Age▪ and by the solemn Oath of St. Sago, Swor not a Hero of fourteen durst pre∣tend to a piece of Gallantry without these Magnifying Glasses, adorn'd his Nose and alter'd his Speech. (puts them on) Do ye understand me Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay
SP.P:
Rediculous—pr'ythee give them me; I'll carry them for a Present to an Old Decay'd Beauty of my Acquain∣quaintance
in England, who always uses Spectacles when she Patches.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: I know who you mean e'en Transport her my close Collar too; 'twill hide the Wrinkles of her Neck, for I am sure it pinches mine intollerably.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: But for Heaven's sake tell me the Reason? When my Lord Ambassadour gives us our full Liberty, and Travailing in his Train as Relations and Men that design only to see the Country and not Inhabit in it; We I say, whose chief aim is Pleasure? Why we should put our selves in pain with the Formality of their incomprehensible Dress? Is indeed to me unacountable Folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Gay-love, you mistake my End—'tis to promote my Pleasure I have done it. I never yet Address'd a Woman but I cou'd hear the Don say to his Servants beware the Eng∣lishman, watch him close, use your Pistol if he proceeds—so I resolve to Mimick their formal Gate, set Speech, and stiff Behaviour, and try what Luck I shall meet with then.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Go on and Prosper—for my part I have no rea∣son to Complain of my Stars as I am—Not long ago I pass'd the Night in the Arms of a melting Beauty, tho' her Father lay Coughing over Head, and her snoring Brother in the next Room.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Have a care Gay-love, some of these Women will be∣betray thee, and thou wilt meet instead of an Embrace, a Stab.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Fear not—Dangers seldom face the Bold—Cowards that fly them they often overtake—But hast thou no particular Amour, no Belle ione, for which thy Ease is Sacrifis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: To confess the Truth I have—there is a Woman or rather an Angel, whose Eyes have power to animate the Dead, she has all the Sweetness, Grace and Majesty, that Nature ever yet bestow'd upon the Fair.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Now must I brag of my Mistress, tho' I have sworn to the contrary—nay, nay, hold ye Friend, I have a Lady shall Shine with her for the best Jewel in the King of Spains Coronet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Go on, go on, we'll not Quarrel, like Mr. Bay's He∣roes whose: amsel is the Handsomest.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: But this Cherbim of mine has such an old Find so her Guardian, ugly as a Monster, and his ill Nature, you may read without my Spectacles, who like a cruel Cerberu as he is, forbids all that approach, only by stol'n Glances from her talking Eyes I fancy my self not disagreeable to her, this is the occasion of my Habit, and for the same Reason Jo is lac'd up to his Chin, and now gone to find me out—a Man whom we must receive like a Grandee, but is indeed.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: a Pimp.—Hearke Bellmour, you shall lend him me if he is Ingenious.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell
SP.P: O a very Mercury—He is at your Service, I'll share all my good Fortune with thee but my Mistress. Now Gay-love, as I have dealt thus openly, I expect the same Freedom, and one Reason that makes me so inquisitie, I sea from thy wild volatile Temper, thou wilt run into inevita∣ble Danger, I find thee often absent and must know the Ad∣venture.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Your Demand has so much kindness in it I cannot de∣ny you—I have a particular Mistress too; whose Beau∣ty I shall not enlarge upon, 'tis sufficient she Charms me, I have often met her at St. Dominicks Chappel.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Why thither my Mistress comes too.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: She has more Wit in her Conversation than in my Life I ever found in the Sex, but her Positive Command is always Secrecy, should she know I told it but to thee, who we't thou Malicious, can do her nor me no harm in it, I dare swear she would never forgive me; she cries Men of your Country are such Blabs, and one step towards a Discovery for ever loses her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: I do not like so much Caution, I should fear some Design.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P:
'Tis not my Nature to suspect—besides I love Intreagues that are not bare-fac'd, now here's Room for my Fancy to work, I can suppose her a Princess, and fill my Head
with a Thousand pleasant Chimera's; Oh there's nothing so Delightful as to have one's Mind full!

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Do you neither know her Name nor where she Lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: No, all our Meetings are by her own Contrivance and I am happy in obeying.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Well, I with you success, but pray be careful. How do you like Don Philip, who joyn'd us in our Voyage; the Ambassadour's Invitation I find pleases him, I believe he is in our Condition, in Love; the Beauty of fair Emilia your Si∣ster, makes him remain with us and continue unknown in Madrid.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: What his Reasons for his Disguise are I know not, but I assure you I think him a Man of a good Understanding and a generous Disposition, nor can I help liking him ex∣treamly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: He Deserves it—see here he comes my Man, and with him the Person I spoke of.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Jo and Gusman bowing all the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Don these are the Gentlemen, who beg your Assistance (aside) the Devil take his Civility, my damn'd Spanish Cloaths are so stif I cannot bend my Body.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Don, being Strangers in this Country and our Busi∣ness Pleasure—we have a desire under your Conduct to sport away some Hours with the Ladies, but knowing that affair difficult in Madrid, we have been directed to you as a Person of an admirable Genius and unequal Cunning.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Sir, I have had the Honour to Serve two Cardinals and as many Abbots and never fail'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: How, Cardinals and Abbots, I doubt you are mista∣ken Bellmour, we rather want one that has serv'd a Libertine.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Oh fy, fy Sir! They can help themselves, 'tis your close Sinners require my Aid.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Worthy Don, I am Convinc'd and crave your Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: My Appellation is, Alonzo de Mendez de Antonia Fer∣dinndo de Gusman.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ay, there's a Name, how sneakingly Poor Jo sounds to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Noble Don Gusman, our first Request is, that you wou'd accept an Acknowledgment (gives Gold) And next that, you would Uouchsafe to instruct this Novice here in Love Affairs, teach him to be useful in this Jealous Country, to Deliver a Letter, Dog a Lady, Deceive (if occasion of∣fers) a Privy Councellour—for we are at present in great Perplexities.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ay faith, two Gypsies have run away with our Hearts, and not left so much as a Track for a Hue and Cry.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I'll do my beast, but is he docible, is he apt.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Hearkee, Hearke pray Mr. Don with a hard Name, do not lead me into Plots and Priminaries: I have had one hearty Drubbing already, for following a Damsel of Darkness, as black as the Devil who set me on.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: You Rogue, 'twas I bid you do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ah Sir, I believe the Old Gentleman Tempted your Worship, so he imploy'd your Humble Servant at second Hand; Providence send me into Merry little England again —where I cou'd Pick up a Lady at the Play-house, carry her Home, and have her Husband invite me to Supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: You Pick up a Lady Raskal—

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Yes Sir I, finer things than these black Flippits with Death and Destruction about them.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: In that Cold Country as I have heard, it requires no Art, no Invention to compass the Fair One; which renders the pursuit Flat and Insipid, here every Faculties imploy'd. This heightens the Joy and inhances the Value of that Pos∣session which costs so dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Don Gusman's an Oracle.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ay but these Dainties are only fit meat for my Masters, why shou'd I share the Danger that want no such Relish. I can eat heartily of Venison if 'tis set before me, without the Pain of Riding over Hedge or Ditch to run it down.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Hold your Tongue Sirrah—and if you have a wretch∣ed smattering towards Wit, imploy it in practising under this worthy Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P:
Gentlemen let me hear the Case of each, tho' at pre∣sent I confess my self in whimsical Circumstances having the
Lady to whom I have vow'd my Heart in Durance vile, for I am in Love my Noble Patrons 'tis that improves the Soul, and elevates the Fancy, this Fellow must be in Love—he'll be good for nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Mr. Don as I called ye before, I desire you would let me alone—and know this I'd chuse to be hang'd at my own English Tyburn ee'r I'd venture being knock'd on the Head, for a Rawbon'd—Spanish—

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Peace Varlet or I'll be worse to thee than all thy Fears. Know thou Machiavel for such I esteem thee at Intrigues, we intend to be this Afternoon at St. Dominicks where we have both beheld these Beautiful Visions—but mine is pursu'd close as her own Shadow by Age, and Deformity, in the wretched Figure of a crooked Old Man; now my desire is you'd take off this odious spy—or at least learn who he is —and because I know you are a Man of urgent and pres∣sing Occasions, make this Blockhead of mine necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Good Sir, let him have the Glory of the Work to him∣self, I am not Ambitious.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Sir conclude your Business done, now I attend to re∣ceive your Instructions.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Faith I must have them first, from my invinsible, I hope you are to be ound upon occasion—or so.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I can't promise yee that, for I long to be confin'd in Walls of Stone and Gates of Brass—O my Lisset.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ah unfortunate Jo. what will become of Thee now, must I in a strange Country follow the Capricio's of a Mad∣man, with his Gates of Stone and Walls of Brass.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Fear not, I will leave thee in safety, and meet you at th Place appointed. Come along Poltron and let me infuse in∣to thee Cunning and Courage.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Do if thou canst, I defy all thy Wisdom to make me Couragious, I leave that to my Betters—I was born a Cow∣ard I don't care who knows it, and hope to dye in a whole Skin, why do you think I was a serving Man else for wages Fellow—if I had been plagu'd with Courage I'de have been a Soldier Man but I love Peace, Laziness and good Eating.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Leave your Speeches Sirrah and march after your Leader.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo
SP.P: I am sure if it is any Wickedness, 'twill never prosper, for I shall say my Prayers vehemently.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Come along Coward.—Gentlemen I am your Humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: Don we are wholly Yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Why how do I know where He is carrying me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: If thou dost not go this very Moment, my Sword shall set the forward Fool!

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: I am gone, I am gone, poor Dear Jo, what will become of thee, I say what will be thy Hard Lot.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Sirrah!

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Well, well good bye—ah, ah.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: This Fellow will never do any good.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: 'Tis the only one I dare trust, the Ambassador's Ser∣vants are too much in awe to meddle with these Affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Sir Don Philip craves a Word with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.L: We attend Him—then to our Amours,
Hereafter we'll be very Grave and Wise
Now we'll be gay, Love laughs in youthful Eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.L: Nor will we stop in the Delightful Race,
Whilst we have strength and vigour for the Chase.

DIV3.HEAD: The SCENE changes into a Garden-House in the Palace of Don Gomez.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Beatrice where is Donna Laura.
part of the Garden-House, that joyns to the Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Tell her I am for a few Moments got rid of my Ty∣rant, and beg her Conversation to relieve my Spirits, sunk with the Weight of continual Torments.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Madam I see her coming—

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: 'Tis well; now I have lost my poor Lisset, whose innocent Mirth reviv'd me, my own Thoughts are only sad Companions.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Ay, that Corrigidore was a great Rogue I am sure, and 'twas more in fear of my Lord's Anger, than out of any Love to Justice he committed her to Prison for only coming in at the Garden-Gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Poor Creature, I long to know how she bears her Con∣finement, Donna Laura promis'd me to send to her, she can Command her Servants, I dare not mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Madam, she is here.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Laura and Lisset in Boy's Cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I have brought you a Present, my Melancholy Dear, that I am sure will please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: What Youth is this?—Ha! My Lissetta thus Disguis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: The very same and your humble Creature ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: My better Angel, how cou'd thou do this.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Mony my Dear—Mony—Mony got Lisset out of Prison, Mony got this Habit, Mony makes those very Servants, which your Monster of a Husband, and my Argus of a Brother design'd for Cruel Spies; become my humble Slaves, and I dare affirm Mony is that Philosopher's Sto, the Graye Studying Fellows meant, and the New, hunt in vain after—for there is no Proof against it's Power; it makes the Old Young, it Conquers Towns without Soldiers, alters the Decrees of Senates, raises Towers from the Dust that touch the Skies; in fine, it is that Golden Elixer, that Spirit of Life, the Old Dons kept such a work about.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: You are always Chearful—but my Lisset I have Mourn'd extreamly for thee, how hast thou pass'd thy time in that loathsome Place.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Why I Sung to one Madam, talk'd to another, and manag'd my self so, that I had the good Fortune to please the whole wretched Crew, they in return endeavour'd to make my Confinement easie, and when this good Lady Brib'd my Keeper for my Escape, tho' they all Griev'd, they promis'd heartily to conceal my Enlargement.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Dear Laura, Faithful Lisset.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: There is no doubt but we are very glad to have her again—but now Clarinda, let us fall upon our own Af∣fairs —You know my time is very short—my Jealous Brother, who plac'd me here, hoping your more Jealous Hus∣band would be a secure Guard, and his Palace as safe as a Pri∣son is, returning from Granada to morrow Night, than I am to be condemn'd to a Twin Brother of your odious Husband's, instead of having a charming Young Thing, always coming near me, Gay and Chirping like a Nightingale; I must be warn'd of his approach, by a hideous uhha, uhha (Coughs) and plagu'd with inquiries if his Flannels be dry, since last Night, when his Ptisick put him into a Convulsion, no rather than I'll Marry him I'll Kill my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Heaven forbid! That sweet Temper should harbour such a cruel Though.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Why dost thou think I'de indure such a Bedfellow as Don Gomez?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Nay, my Lady has the Comfort of a separate Bed, and he don't trouble her often, for in all my Time, I never hear'd the Door Unbolt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Why! Hast thou a Bolt to the inside my Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Yes, yes I am secure enough a Nights, but he is re∣venged on me by Day,—whilst you can Steal out to what Church or Chappel you please, and poor I must always have him my Jaylor at my Heels, methinks your Life's as pleasant as your Heart can desire, for all your Brother's Seve∣rity as you manage it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P:
True, and I have more Conveniencies than you Imagine, Clarinda observe sometimes great Politick's shoot wide of the Mark, as he did when he took that Maxim—I shou'd command what Money I pleased, least others shou'd tempt me with the shining Dross—this is an Ingredient as I
told you before; with which I purchase some Stol'n Delights as a little Ramble, a good deal of Harmless Chit Chat, and such Trifles as our sex (especially when they are lock't up are fond of—but now 'tis Ten to One whether an Old Hus∣band prove of this Liberal Disposition, therefore I am resol∣ved for Freedom.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: And Mr. Gay-love the Ambassador's Kinsman is to be assistant in the Grand Affair—ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: That's more than he knows, I am very angry with him, and that he shall know—he has broke my com∣mands, but my Dear there's another handsome Fellow that's always with the Ambassadour's Kinsman—You Blush.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: No—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Ah Duce on him, 'twas parleying with him, cau∣sed me to be shut out of the Garden Gate, bless me, what a fright I was in when my Key wou'd not open the Door and and I heard old Ruttle in the Throat Don Gomez on the o∣ther side—

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: But Laura, how shall we contrive to Conceal her, now we have got her agen; Oh Heavens! He is coming [Noise without the back way] in and there's no Escaping.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: What shall we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Fear nothing Ladies, I'll remember, I did wear an Apron and find some excuse, I warrant ye his blind Eyes will ne'er discover me in this Dress, I remember I put once Gus∣man upon him for my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Ah poor Gusman I dare say, he is in Dispair for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Now I shall try his Love, first here comes Old Satan I'll stand back and Invent.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: So got together Caballing, Contriving, Plotting,—ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: We have been studying indeed.—

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Mischief I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: No, a thing we could not find out, even what Old Men are good for.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Confidence to my Face—well thy Brother left me all the Plagues of Egypt, when he gave me thee in charge —ha, what have we here (Sees Lisset) a thing in Bree∣ches, what's your Name, what's your Business, what are you ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: What am I Sir—I am a Man and no Man, I bear the outward Figure of a Man, but in Reality am an Eu∣nuch.—

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: An Enuch, good lack—how came you hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Ay Madam how came I hither—now help me out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Why my Brother sent him from Granada as he was going to the Grand Seignior.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Oho, did he so!

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I suppose it is some cross piece; else I shou'd not have had the Present.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Ods me an Eunuch! That's not amiss, and what are you good for I pray?—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: To Watch Virgins and Spoil Intreagues.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Humph, that's very well

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: I'll tell you Sir; I was chief Eunuch to the Beglerbeg of Tunis—I got the good Will of him, and the ill Will of his whole Female Seraglio—Odso, if I saw but the least Inclination, ay the smallest Symptom—You under∣stand me my Lord—I plagu'd them till the Fools took up with Wall and Oatmeal and never thought of a Man a∣gain.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: A useful Fellow this is—Odsme I begin to grow fond of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: And why did you not stay in your Seraglio at Tunis? ve had Torments enough without you.

SP.SPEAKER: Go
SP.P: Madam pray hold your Peace, he speaks like an Ho∣nest Person—Friend what may I call you?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Liscias my Lord,—Don Lewis who bought me at Granada, said there were here two dangerous slippery Fe∣males; I have found them out, and my Lord if I don't ma∣nage them, till I make them as Lean as Skelitons and as Cross as Crooked Maids of Fifty, Condemn me to the Gallies instead of a Reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Here's a Rogue now.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: O he is a Treasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: I have Letters by way of Recommendation in my Portmantua, from your Devoted Friend Don Lewis.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Those at leasure I will peruse

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: But I must Counterfeit them first, and that I can do old Don.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Liscias thou art Welcome—why have we not Eu∣nuchs in Spain? Oh 'tis an admirable Custom and useful Po∣licy —Odso, I believe it upholds the Tukish Empire—for when these she Devils Converse publickly, they will med∣dle in Politicks and always do Mischief—these are the Women—canst thou undertake them?—Ha!—canst thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss
Go.
SP.P: Happy Man to meet with such a Blessing, Why han't we Eunuchs in Spain? I say, why have we no Eunuchs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: We have abundance of Old Men, and that's much the same thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Well, well Mrs. Pert, I hope to see you Married to one to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: That's more than I deserve, and you have less.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: How's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Why you deserve to have Horns—Horns over those Glasses, I mean your Spectacles and false Eye—but your Wife's too Virtuous.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Hear you this Mr. Eunuch, let me intreat you to be Careful—I can scarce trust any Body—I had a vile Baggage, an instrumental Baggage, Lisset they call'd her, but she's safe enough, she shall not leave her strong Hold, 'till I send her to the West Indies to play her Tricks there.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: What do I hear? How my Heart akes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: You punish her because she Lov'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Ay you'll suffer some unmerciful Judgment for that Barbarity, you will so ye Old—ye Adam's Grandfather, ye will.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: No matter for that—I shou'd have suffer'd an Un merciful one if she had been at Liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Hang her Hilding—let us mind our own Business.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Well said my Dear Eunuch—I am not so Old nei∣ther as these Tormenters would make me Liscias, 'tis true my Sight's bad, that's the worst of me Dear Liscias, and these Crocodiles know it and abuse me beyond all bearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: I know it too—or I were in a sweet Condition

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Well Gentlewomen—as you dread being Lock'd up for three—I charge you be Civil to my Eunuch—my Dear Eunuch.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Monster.—

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: He can make no Monster Mistress, that's your Grief I suppose—um, this good Fortune has given me more ease than I have known this twelve Month—I will Petition the King and Councel that we may have a Colony of these use∣ful and yet not dangerous Signs of Men; odso, it was the wisest thing Don Lewis ever did to send him—Our Duen∣na's have a Remembrance of past Pleasures, and receive De∣light in beholding Wickedness, the Sparks revive and glow their old, old Wanton Veins, to see the Love and fooleries of Youth, but an Eunuch—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Hates what he never can possess upon my Word, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: True my Dear Liscias, 'tis natural, come my best Guar∣dian and Regale with me thou sha't want for nothing but —but—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: I understand you my Lord—yet must ask your Pardon there—if you trust the Woman with me, I shall never have them out of my sight, I thank ye Sir I know them too well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: So we are to have a perpetual Plague I find.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: How won't thou not go with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss
SP.P: No my good Lord—why we had a young Wo∣man once (indeed it was her first Love, and then they are very eager) and what do think she did.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: By'th Mass I know not—what did she do Liscias —what did she do.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Knaw'd away through an Iron Bar with her Teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha they were very good Teeth I assure ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: No she was sharp set—Madam—Mon∣strous Woman.—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Then another time, we tryed Wooden Bars, and a fu∣rious Damsel got them asunder with her French Twizers—therefore I'll not undertake them if my Eyes be not their Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Prodigious Care—well—well take thy own Way—odso we must confer longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: We will, we will, but now leave me to give them In∣structions.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Do, do, tell them the Vanity of Love—farewel Jewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: I am enjoyn'd by my Confessour to go to Day to St Dominicks Chappel.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: I'll be with you again by that time, your Confessour ah he is good for nothing but to promote Opportunities. I believe he loves to make Work for Confession—Liscias let your Documents be very severe my Dear Man of I'ce, let 'em be sharp I say—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Vinegar and Gall I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Very well, good bye, byt'h Mass 'tis very well—however I'll lock the Door, for all my new Favourite.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I thought so but I am provided for ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: My Dear Euauch. (kisses her)

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: It must be an Eunuch indeed, such a Kiss wou'd warm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Odso, I think we are happy byt'h Mass as the Old Man says we are. Hussy how durst you call your self so near your own Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: 'Twas at my Tongues End Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Now employ that wondrous Stock of Wit Heaven has bestowed upon you, stretch thy Invention Girl and be∣fore to morrow set us free.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Can you be free.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: That time shall try; let's make a busie Day perhaps I may get Courage to tell ye strange things e'er Night be∣gins her Sable Reign.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Romantick; I am sure I long to be upon the Wing, nay out of sight, before my Tyrant Brother seizes me.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: And truly Ladies I can't help thinking a little of my own Love—forgive me, your Favour makes me bold.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: We love thee Dear Lisset.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: I believe these Cloaths, and a Patch on my Fore∣head would conceal me, even from Gusman. I am resolved now I am got in Breeches, I'll make all the use I can of them; I dare venture any thing, my first Attempt succeeds so well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.L: We'll in, and Consult.
'Tis Liberty's each Mortals chief Delight
The Soveraign Good to which all plead a Right,
My Friend when Liberty and Love inspires
We cannot fail to compass our Desires.

DIV3.TRAILER: The End of the first Act.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Philip.
SP.P: IS it possible there shou'd be such a Villain in the World as Don Gomez; but why should I wonder at it, when he hir'd the very Men that car∣ryed me to the Indies to kill me, which one amongst them dis∣covering —I to prevent his further practises, sent the Fellow that proved Honest, back; to assure him of my Death, till I cou'd find means to get with safety into Spain to claim my Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: Upon the welcome News of your Death, he imme∣diately seiz'd your Estate, and poor Clarinda whom he has us'd as I told you.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Phil.
SP.P: Viper! But you say he stands in Fear of the Arch-Bishop of Toledo, and dares not proceed further.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: No I think he will not; till he is got into the West-Indies, which is his full Design, as soon as he can get his Effects into Mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Phil.
SP.P: Clarinda's going I shall take care to prevent, in the mean time faithful Pedro be secret in my return—I shall reward thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: I'de Dye e'er I reveal a Word against the Noble Youth, whom from his Infancy I have lov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I do believe thee—but now withdraw I expect Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: The Powers protect yee.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Ladies your Servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Is your Consort ready? This Lady and I, at your De∣sire are come to hear it; but where's my Brother and Kins∣man? Did you not tell us they promised to be with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Phil.
SP.P: Faith and so they did heartily; but I hope the Fair Sex of that Nation are stricter in the Engagements than the Gentlemen, for they often serve me thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: That dear Brother of mine is so wild, and in this Country 'tis so dangerous, that I am in a continual Fear for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Phil.
SP.P: 'Tis pity any passion shou'd possess that dear Snow'y Bosom, but melting Love—your Eyes have given me.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Hold Don Phillip—you know you promised to learn our English Customs, and conform to those, now as our Women allow all Innocent Diversions, and frequently con∣verse with Men—yet they are cautious how they listen to the Tale of Love; Consider, long before they trust their Hearts, and give that dear priz'd Freedom from them.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I'll do what ever you command, if you kindly will construe all I as meant to express my Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Sir the Musick's ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Pray let them begin for we cannot stay long from the Ambassador's Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Bid them enter.

DIV3.HEAD: Songs and Dances.
DIV3.STAGE: After Musick entér Gay-Love out of Breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: What is the Musick done—I swear I have run like a contending Chairman to be with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: You have lost a good Entertainment I assure ye, pray where have you been in this great Hurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Oh Sister upon the most foolish Adventure.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: So they are all in my Opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P:
I followed a woful Chase, as it proved—up one Street and down another, using all my Rhetorick to a Hood∣winck'd Gentlewoman to unvail; I cannot behold the Wo∣men shut up like a Hackney Coach, but I must long to see
the inside, if I were to be hang'd; at last after intreating, vowing, protesting and all that, in a Tone that gave me the first Fright. Be quiet impertinent said she, and let me a∣lone (mimicking an Old Womans Voice without Teeth) then throw'd up her Vail, and showed me fourscore and five.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: At which I ran as if the Devil drove me, and lost my Breath as you saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: But what's become of Belmour?

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Oh I tipped him the wink, to leave me, when I un∣dertook this notable Design—and where he is I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I hope upon such another, I wou'd have you meet with nothing but with Disappointments to cure your wildness.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Oh your servant Sister that won't do; I have a Mi∣stress, and she has Rosy Cheeks, Sparkling Eyes, Cherry Lips, and an Alabaster Skin, which she her self discover'd with an Ecce Signum Monseir.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Fie, fie, well but now you have recovered your Breath, I'll tell you what you shall do, for your Punishment in being absent when Relations come to visit you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ay Relations—you know Sister.—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I know you, but you shall sing us a Song, Sir do you hear that.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Pshaw I have none but rambling Songs, your Gravi∣ty won't like.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Well for once I'll dispense with my Gravity rather than your Performance.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Say you so—have at you then.

DIV3.HEAD: A Song by a Gentleman, sung by Mr. Laurence.
DIV3.L: Bright Cloe first, with Love inflam'd my Heart;
The Subtle Lightning Flew thro' every part,
Pleasures unknown before, my Soul Surprise,
For all the Grace's triumph'd in her Eyes.
In all she did, in every thing she said,
Some nice peculiar Beauty was displayed.
Thus was I charm'd; but soon the cruel Fair,
My Hopes deceiv'd, and doom'd me to despair.
No Arts prevail'd, to conquer her desdain:
I beg'd, and sigh'd, and vow'd, but all in vain.

DIV4.HEAD: Second Movement.
DIV4.L: As the Curse I lamented of being deny'd;
Gay Cupid descending, fond lover, he cry'd.
Never languish beneath a coy Womans disdain,
Love was meant for a Pleasure, and not for a Pain;
And when e'er a proud Heart does forbid you to enter:
Give it o're, and search out for another Adventure.
This Advice like a Cordial reliev'd my sick Mind;
So I went to Larissa the Gentle, the Kind:
To her with what ease I my Passion reveal'd!
For she met me half-way; so we sign'd and we seal'd.
But profuse of her Favours she granted so fast,
Love's Riot was grown too expensive to last.
So I left the fond Fool, tho' a Fool of my making,
And attended Love's call for a new undertaking.

DIV4.HEAD: Third Movement.
DIV4.L: Thus, thus the cruel and the kind,
Can never fix my roving Mind.
The one torments, the other Cloys;
And each the tast of Love destroys.
But he, that will his bliss improve,
Is true to change as well as Love.
And like a Bee, collects his Sweets,
From every Fragant Flower he meets.
Then hear me love, propitious, be,
And give me Dear variety.

DIV3.HEAD: A Song.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Go you are very Wicked why you'll never recommend your self to our Sex if you profess in∣constancy

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: And that's strange now they shou'd not like what they daily practise.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I must leave you my Aunt has sent for me, come Madam. Don Philip accept our Thanks for the excellent Musick

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Oh Madam mention it not; my concealment in Ma∣drid hinders me from performing what I wou'd have done —Ladies give me Leave to wait on you thro' the Lodg∣ings.—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: My Brother will I suppose save you the Trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: No, no, let him, let him, I must stay here.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Well, thou art a sad young Rougue.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Your Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Oh your Servant, your Servant, wait of a Sister Quoth he—when one's Head's as full of Intrigues as it can hold. Not yet three.

DIV3.P: Oh how how I long to go to Church—Gusman and Bellmour's Blockhead to meet me at the Corner by the great Cross right.

DIV4.HEAD: A Leter tied to a Stone, drops at his Feet, he takes it up and looks about.
DIV4.P: He what have we here? Not a Message from above, I hope to stop my Carreer—no, no, 'tis a Womans Hand, that never dropt from the Sky, I am sure—Humph—what's this?

DIV4.HEAD: A Letter.
Reads.
DIV4.P: You are a perfidious, perjured, (so) odious tittle tattle English∣man (very well) did not I charge you to be secret and silent (a so yo did that's true) and have not you like a false Villain and a Traytor (Ha she has a good Hand at calling Names I'le say that for Her) told Bellmour all you knew (Ha) therefore the fairy Trea∣sures Vanish'd—Go lye between your Coughing Father, and Sno∣ring Brother, but expect no more to engage with a Woman of Ho∣nour —Blab—well extreamly well but who told her this now? Why none but Bellmour for only to him 'twas told—Ha! a sudden thought undoes me, it must be the same Woman he follows—but then How poor he is to sacrifice the Secrets of his Friend to buy a Favour at my Expence—fair one you mistake Bellmour's the Traytor and a Villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: What's that my Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Do not prophane the Name—all other Countries, even those we hold the meanest, protect Love and maintain their Fellow Country men—only the English whose de∣light is to undermine, backbite and betray—They worship strangers but not ruine one another. Draw—

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: What Means this Accusation—Draw—art thou Mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: No; but there's something thou hast done—so much beneath the Name of Friend that I resolve to cut the Union, nor ever trust a Man again. Draw I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Pr'ythee be quiet and tell me the Occasion of this Frenzy.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay
SP.P: There's no Room for expostulation when there can be no excuse—Defend thy self for I shall give no Li∣mits to my Passion; let me not mistrust another Vice which shou'd indeed attend thy Crime—Cowardise.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Ha Young Man thy Tongue may give me Wounds may smart too much—and raise thy Folly as high as thine

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: You see I stand prepared to prevent then the Galling suspition; dally no longer.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Well angry thing,—let me change my sword and I am for yee, I scorn odds, and thy Friendship.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Nay, come on with that, I will not stay another Moment.

DIV4.STAGE: Lisset, seems to leap down behind the Scenes, and runs in.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Hold ye'r Dead doing Hand you little Man of migh∣ty Courage—know Bellmour is Innocent—she heard her self your fair Confession—you have each of you a Mistress—which are just now going to St. Dominick's, and if you stay fooling here, you'll loose the best Opportunity.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: I am amaz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: From whence come yee, or what are you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: No matter for that,—I am one born to do the good—let me out of the Street Door will ye.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Did you come over the Garden Wall?—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Lard, lard how slow you English are—and how ungrateful—when a Man has a kindness done him to re∣turn it with asking Questions, I did not stand shall I, shall I, when I was to save you from committing Murder here—will you let me out or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: I will without another word—Thou little Gana∣mede whom I'll suppose to descend upon Jupiter's Eagle.—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Ay, ay, do so, do so, but now I must be gone.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: I dare not look towards Bellmour—hang't I will return and bear the Brunt—come fairy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: What a strange Enigma's here—tho' this is plain I have just reason to be angry with Gaylove, but I love the Youth and that will plead his Cause—

DIV4.STAGE: Re-enter Gaylove. He stands a good way off, and looks down.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Is all our Years of happy Friendship then no more; but Death upon a bare suspicion—was this well done?

SP.SPEAKER: Gay,
SP.P: No—yet read that (throws him the Letter he reads) and then forgive my Passion—to tell as I thought my pri∣vate Sins to my Mistress—the very particulars; that sno∣ring and coughing made me Mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: And wou'd you not show me this first—but seek my Life upon a Woman's scrawl; perhaps a false one who hires spies and will at last betray you—'twas poor and cannot be forgiven I'll never meet yee more. (is going)

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Then turn back and use your Sword for now my Blood is cool, I'd rather loose my Life than loose your Friend∣ship.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: I cannot look on thee, and bear resentment; I'll ne∣ver meet thee more but thus (embrace him) this is real and all my Angers feigned.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Blessed be thy kind forgiving Nature, you have Judg∣ment and Goodness—henceforth you shall be my Guide.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: All's well; bu pray be cautious—methinks this Woman's too cunning to be Honourable.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: I will obey you in every thing—now Dear Friend let us go to St. Dominick's; where you know we are promised to see both our Mistresses.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
Gay.
SP.L: 'Tis so; I am as much surpris'd as you.
Yet must persue the Hid uncertain Fair,
When Beauty tempts who can avoid the Snare.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to a Street in Madrid.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P:
I have Instructions from Donna Laura to amuse this English Coward, Jo. but not Discover who they are 'tis a
venial Sin, I'm sure to take Bribes on both Sides—but whom do I gather Wealth for, now my Love, my Life, my dear Lysset is gone; I'll be in Prison that's resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Well; Where are you now? When will they come? I long till 'tis over.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Oh they'll be here presently—But are you per∣fect in your Story?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Yes, Yes, I am perfect enough; but I believe I shan't say a Word on't when the grim old Fellow looks me in the Face.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: How Man—then you are undone if he finds you out for an Impostor, I wou'd not give you a Marvedis for your Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Oh—Oh—

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Why you will be put upon the Wrack, or Heaven knows what will become of ye—

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: The Wrack; a Lard, a Lard—I'll down upon my Knees to my Lord Ambassador to be sent into England, tho' I travel all the Way upon my bare Feet; for I don't care to go Home by Sea again neither—I was frighted too much when I came—

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: You are very likely indeed to go from Spain Home by Land—Come, come, observe my Directions, and fear nothing—

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Wou'd you could teach me that Don Director: But won't ye be far off then if I should cry out Murder—

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: No, no; remember your great Desire to see Mexico.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Yes, Yes; but I'll be hang'd as soon as taken at my Word, for I promise you I have no Mind to travel far∣ther.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Your Business is to draw the Old Man from the Young ones, with the Story I have put in your Mouth; keep him off whilst your Masters entertain the Ladies; then, at Notice, trn him loose—shift for your self, and your Affair is over, and your Reward certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Would it were—

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I see 'em coming, Farewel and Prosper

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: And I feel my Fit of Trembling come upon me—What Devil bewitches me to venture thus for these mad Ma∣sters of mine—They did not beget me sure, I have such a natural Affection for them—One would think I should love my own Carcass best, and not run the Risk of suffering the Pain—to give them Pleasure—Well, if I do come off, 'twill be a rare Story in England with some Flourishes of my own—Ah, here they are—Oh my Heart, it thumps, thumps like a Smith's Anvil.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Don Gomez, Clarinda, Laura veild, Don Gomez talk∣ing to Lisset, followed at a Distance by Gaylove and Bellmour.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Go.
SP.P: Lyscias, Lyscias—I am satisfy'd—I am con∣vinc'd of thy Care—and thy Relation of the Govern∣ment of the Turkish Women is Surprising—Good—Ad∣mirable —Odso—I will endeavour to bring it up here in Spain; They never go to Church—Lyscias—ha—

SP.SPEAKER: Lys.
SP.P: Never—

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Excellent—there is more Mischief done at Church in Spain Lyscias—than we imagine—look to these Women to Day, my dear Eunuch—they had a great Inclination to come abroad, and Women's Inclinations are prone to Evil, odso—

SP.SPEAKER: Lisc.
SP.P: Be Easie—be Contented—my Vigilance shall prevent their Wishes.

DIV3.STAGE: [All the while they are talking, Jo is preparing to speak to Go∣mez, but still starts back.]

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Most Noble Don [bowing very low] descended from the Renown'd Family of the Alcantara's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau,
SP.P: Mind Clarinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: I have look'd at him a good while

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Some Trick I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Gom.
SP.P: What wouldst thou have Friend, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Illustrious Don! I am my self from a lineal Degree, a Branch of Charlemain.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: It may be; What is that to me, ha, Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: I shall be out; Carrying in my Veins the Blood of Kings, hitherto I have disdain'd all servile Work—till I could find a Man Great and Brave enough to force this stubborn Heart to buckle too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Buckle too! well said Charlemain's Grandson.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Now 'tis accomplish'd if the thrice Heroick Don Go∣mez will vouchsafe his Ear, I would attend him to the Realms of Mexico; yea, I would kiss the Lappit of his Shoe Tie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: The Shoe Tie of his Lappit I suppose you mean, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Well what's that to you what he means—Li∣scias, if what he says proves Truth, I am sent another Bles∣sing. I wanted Persons to serve me that knew my Worth—Odso—I will examine him, but dare not talk of Mexico before the Women—Come on with me Friend—Lyscias be careful—this may prove a Cheat; we must be wathful Lyscias.

SP.SPEAKER: Lysci.
SP.P: To be sure—

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Mercy on me; What will be my Destiny now—He can't murder me in the Church tho', that's one Comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Triumphant Jo—

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: What was that a Engine of yours then, carry'd off the old Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Certainly you see Madam what Pains we take for these Transitory Moments of Happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: By that untoward Bar to Bliss, just remov'd, you should be the Lady I adore; you have it in your Power to Banquet all our Senses; you ought to Feast our Eyes at least—let us behold your Beauties—

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Dear Lisset, watch the Passage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lysc.
SP.P: Be Couragious Ladies—I may see him a vast way before he can come upon you. I'll go out and stand in the Passage—

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Do, Do, now then look your Worst, we dare stand the Test, for all your Fam'd English Beauties—(they unveil.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: So bright Aurora with her Rosy Fingers, draws the black Curtains of the ugly Night, and darts a thousand Glo∣ries round.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: There's Heroicks now; What says your Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: My Transports cannot be express'd—But are you two Friends? Methinks you seem by Heaven designd our lovely Lots, to make us equal in Bliss, as in our Fortunes and Friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Alas you know us not—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: No, but we would fain: Come then, improve the flying Minutes, and tell us quickly—I hope you are Sin∣gle —and that old cross Don is a great Uncle, a Grandfa∣ther, or so, whom you have too much Wit to scruple Diso∣beying—

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Let your Companion ask that Question—it con∣cerns him most. For my part I am free, saving some few Promises made for me, which I intend not to perform; I have a Spanish Brother indeed, who has given his Word, where I resolve to give neither Heart nor Hand, I can tell him that—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: I must kiss the fair dear Hand for the kind Resolution, since I will believe it for my Good. (This while Belmour and Clarinda talk.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Hold Madam, [Hastily] if you have any Value for a Life wholly Dedicated to your Service, do but feel what a cold Sweat I am in.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: 'Tis in vain to mince the Matter; that Aegyptian Mummy, that old dry Bones—is her Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Oh, I shall Faint.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Faint! Bear up Man—why, by the Law of Na∣tions, and of Nature, he must be punish'd for such a Piece of horrid Impudence; and she has too much Beauty, and too much Fire, not to do it the sweetest Way—

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Ay, but I have a foolish thing call'd Virtue, a great∣er Tyrant than my Husband; for I consent to her Dictates, which I never did to become that Monster's Wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Must I then Despair—

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Pish, Pish, Despair, Women's Minds never holds two Hours; Despair Quoatha—pursue I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Well said Spirit—so I will thee to the West and East Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Ah Falshood—I know thee to be the most un∣constant Creature Breathing—Were not you this very Morning at Confession—what have you forgot that, and my Resentment? You knew, I suppose, that I'd forgive ye—I find an Englishman true to one Woman, nay, even before he has had her, is a Miracle.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Faith 'tis a greater how you over heard our Discourse. I dreaded no Witchcraft from a fine Woman but her Eyes—Now I begin to fancy my Nurses Story's Authentick—that you have at your Command a little Emissary, who has Power to creap thro' an augur Hole, whisk in at Window's pass, and repass like a Jugler's Ball; deceive the Sight, and discover the Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: That I believe is impossible—but I shall do my best—we Spanish Women are indefatigable in our Love and Revenge; I know you a Rover.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: P'shaw Madam, you must never believe our Sex when they speak to one another of yours—if they boast of a Lady's Favour, ten to one they Lie, if they complain, 'tis odds they are Happy—there's no Measures, Madam, to be taken from what they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Ah, but one may Guess shrowdly by the Manner, whether the Gallant be successful or not—I like a Lover best that is silent; will not so much as let his Eyes declare to any but his Mistress, the State of his Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: 'Tis strange to see the Difference! Now our Country Ladies wou'd not give a crooked Pin for a Spark that did not proclaim his Passion in every publick Place he came into—but Madam, henceforward conclude me Dumb, except in your Presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Well, I am willing to bury all past Faults in Oblivi∣on —provided you give me your Hand and Honour to pursue no more Adventures in Madrid, but List your self, Person, Heart and all under my Command.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P:
Agreed—yet methinks 'tis but just I should know whom I serve, least any petty stragling Officer should
pretend to take me up—Then naming my great Com∣mandress —they drop their Claims, and leave me free.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I am afraid you are utterly unacquainted with one Virtue that's absolutely necessary in a Lover—Patience Friend Patience—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: I confess, when my Appetite's Craving and the Food Delicious, I hate a long Grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Ay, but when the same Dish is serv'd up every Day, you care not a Farthing whether you sit down to Table or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Hu'm, O my Conscience, we were made for one another, you understand me so well—let me speak my very Soul to you; on such a Feast I could live a great while.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: A great while! I am for ever, and for aye, 'till Death us do part.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Pough! What a dismal Sound has that joyn'd to Love—but I submit, take me, let it be any way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I have your Word—no new Amours.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: I tell ye, I won't so much as think of another Wo∣man—Nay, if the Ladies should advance to make me Offers, I'd be as Coy as a Court Nymph to a Country Clown with a small Estate, for with a great one any Rank, Booby will down, and as constant—

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Now quickly a Smile for that—'tis a little out of your Way Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: As Constant as a Stale Maid, who is convinc'd, if she loses her only Fool, she cannot get another.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Well, I am content; Now what have our Friends resolv'd on?

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: All I can get is Complaints; but neither Hopes no a Discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: What she preaches Patience too—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I am sure I had need of a great deal my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Upon my Life he's coming, and in a great Passion too.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: What in this Uncertainty?—

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: I'll stay and cut his Throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Lard, Lard, you are so Passionate—if you have any Love for us retire, or any regard for our Safeties; upon my Word and Honour you shall here from us to Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: That Danger to your selves, and that Promise to us, makes us fly from ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Remember we are wholly yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Well they are pretty Fellows I'll swear Lisset; I'll have a Jant when old Crosness yonder has lock'd us up; you know my false Key, and my Page shall manage—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Dear Madam let us, for I want to look after Gusman a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Clarinda, you'll not venture.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Not I; you do not know my Danger, nor how Desperate my Tyrant is—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: He is just here—seem going into the Church, whilst I stop ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Let us pass, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: You shall not go in till my Lord comes back; What you have some Assignation—let him wait and be hang'd to him, let him wait.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Don Gomez pulling Jo by the Collar.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Well said Liscias—but here's a Rougue whom I have caught in fourscore Lies, nay, if I say a Hundred—I should not tell one—Sirrah, Raskal, Hell-hound, con∣fess, or I Poinard thee; Where wert thou born?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: At la White Chappella near le Tour indeed and indeed—and wou'd I were there up to my Neck in the Ditch with all my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: What shall I do to bring him off? Bless me Madam, [looking at Jo amaz'd] is not this the Madman that us'd to make us Sport under our Windows, and talk of King Pepin, and Charlemain, and I know not what—I did not ob∣serve him before.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: How, Mad—

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Act the Madman Sirrah, or you are undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Sure I may do that, for I am out of my Wits for fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: And us'd to Sing Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Sing Quoatha.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: 'Tis impossible he had Connexion in his Roguery!

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: I must try, what do I see—

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Look how he Stares.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: The reverend Form of good King Pepin.

DIV3.HEAD: Sings.
DIV3.L: Pepin had a Head as white as Snow,
His Eye Brows Grey, his Beard was black blow.
Black below, black below.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Sirrah stand off, or I'll have the Strapado for ye—I'll bring ye out of your mad Fit Sirrah, I will so.

DIV3.STAGE: [Canes him. He Drivels and Cries like a Changling.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: ee, ee, ee, ee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Are you not asham'd to strike a Changling?

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: I'll Changeling him—He thought he had Wit enough to make a Fool of me. Where are my Servants there?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: [Crying out] Ola, Ola, nothing will do.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Oh spare him my good Lord, spare him; 'tis a Tur∣kish Prophet; Madmen are all Inspir'd; He can Prophesy, I am sure he can.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Yes, mark me; Justice shall prevail in every Court of Christendom; yea, the Horns of the Cuckold, shall be tran∣splanted from the Husband's Head, and visibly fix'd upon the Cuckold-makers; yea, the Husband shall help to tie them on.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: See how his Brain runs upon Cuckolding—For thy sake Lyscias I'll leave the Rogue unpunish'd—But let's immediately Home agen; this is an evil Day; I will inconti∣nently return; bar up my Doors Liscias, and keep out ill Luck.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Then you must lock out your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Does that Fellow look like a Madam—uh—

DIV3.HEAD: Jo. Sings.
DIV3.L: Pepin had a Head as white as Snow,
His Eye Brows grey, and his Beard was black below, black below, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Abuse a Grandee of Spain—get ye Home ye Bag∣gages, you bring these Misfortunes upon me with your gad∣ding abroad—you do so—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Ay, ay, Home, Home, that's the properest place for Women.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Right Liscias, away with them, away with them.

DIV3.STAGE: (Exeunt the Ladies followed by Gomez and Lisset.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Now I know I shou'd follow them; but the Devil shall take my place, and do it himself for Jo, if he will; my Fear has made me feel the Poinard at my Throat, and the Strapado on my Back: Oh Curse upon Spain I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Joy, Joy, Don Josephus you have pass'd the Adven∣ture like a Knight Errant, and may come to be as useful in your Generation—I was near, if the Danger had grown eminent.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Yes, you appear when the Mischief's over, witness my Shoulders. You are like your Countrymen, run a Man thro, and then beg his Pardon for the Mistake. Joy Quoatha! Well, I declare I had rather be a Carman in England, nay, a Carman's Horse, than the greatest Pimp in Spain.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Why have ye no Pimps in England then?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P:
Yes marry have we; but they have otherguess Im∣ployments than yours—They are in no Fear of the Stab or the Strapado; there a Pimp dines with a Lord, nay, often comes himself to Preferment by his Vocation, and is only call'd a Friend to Love, one who delights in doing good Of∣fices,
and desires when Parties meet Tete a Tete, there should be a right Understanding between them. Here's nothing but Drudgery and Danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Well your Task is over, and your Master stays for you at the great Cross.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: There's nothing but Crosses in Spain—from them and Intreagues in this damn'd jealous Country, deliver me, and that's poor Jo's Prayer.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Whilst I for others Act, I am my self undone; my Nymph's in Prison, won't thou help me break it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Oh your Servant, your Servant, not I faith break Prisons! Your very humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.L: I must be with her.
I'll pluck some Reverend Don by the Whiskers.
I'll rob a Church, and Sacrilege commit,
But I will be confin'd with dear Lisset.

DIV3.HEAD: The Scene changes to the Piazza under the House of Gomez and the Ambassador's.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Here stands the Walls, and there's the Window from whence Lisset has shew'd many a Favour; the Place remains, but the dear Ornament is gone; I'll try to pick the Lock, and so be sent to Prison.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter a Boy with a Silver Bason under his Coat. A Noise with∣out, stop him, stop him, Thief.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: If I cou'd get into the Ambassador's Court, I were safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: That you shall not Sir; come, come, deliver me your Baggage, and run for your Life you Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Take it—and be hang'd with it—the Ow∣ner's at your Heels, I can tell you that.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: This Way, this Way the Rogue ran.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: Neighbour—Neighbour, mind that Fellow, me∣thinks he looks damn'd suspiciously.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Who I?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Yes you Sir; Who are you? What's your Name? Where do you live?

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Am Sir, I am a Philosopher—my Name's Quibus, I live in Antego.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Raskal, do you banter a Man that has lost a Silver Bason; What's that bunches out under his Cloak? search him, search him.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Search him, search him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Ay, search him, search him.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Why ye impudent Rogue, is not here the Piece of Plate?

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Why ye impudent Rogue, who says to the contrary?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
Gus.
SP.P: I hope so.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: Ay, ay, before the Corrigidore with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Prithee, my dear Blockheads, do not delay time: I confess the Fact; hurry me to Prison, and never stay to have me before a Fool in Authority.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Oh Impudence! He speaks Treason; as if a Man in Authority cou'd be a Fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: Away with him, away with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Make hast, make hast; you can't oblige me more.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: This is the merriest Rogue that ever I met with; Sir∣rah, Hanging, &c. will change your Note.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: No matter for that; away with me, I say.

DIV3.STAGE: As they are going off, Enter Gaylove pulling in Lisset.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Nay faith, my little Ganemede—now I have caught ye alone, you shall not pass Examination.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Well—well, what wou'd you know?

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ha! what have we here Gusman, honest Gusman, i the Paws of the Law—what has he done?

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Stole a Silver Bason, an't please your Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Gusman a Thief, that's impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Shallow Monsters, I shall lose my Drift; I am a Thief.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Thou art so in Troth; Sir he confesses it, and here's the Bason found upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Well, and you have your Bason agen Sir, and there's Money for your Trouble, and something for the Officers to drink.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: Thank your Honour—Friend thou art free; down on your Knees, and pray for the Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
Liss.
SP.P: Faithful Gusman, this is for love of me, that's certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: The Devil, to be thus disappointed so near one's Hopes; I tell ye I will go to Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: Ha, ha; I ne'er saw the like Friend—Friend thou may'st go to Jay l fast enough; for my part I can hardly keep out on't, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: This Humour is past my Understanding—I confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Smith.
SP.P: Heavens Bless you Master for helping a poor work∣ing Man—mighthap the young Fellow may be distem∣per'd in his Mind I shall trouble you no farther Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Why Gusman!

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Gusman, me no Gusman; you have undone me.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Friend, may one presume to ask the Reason of this violent Desire of yours for a Stone Doublet, and an Iron pair of Breeches—as one may say.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: I sav'd ye out of pure good Will.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Pox take your ill-tim'd Kindness—this was in Jest it seems—but I will steal.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: And be hang'd in Earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I'll murder a Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: And be broke upon the Wheel.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: No matter—let me pass, I will to Prison, and I must.

DIV3.L: For I am but a walking Shadow here,
Whilst my ador'd Lisset lies bury'd there

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Is the Man Mad? Do you know any thing of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: A little; but that's nothing to our Purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: True. Answer me then to what is—tell me her Name I say.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Laura cover'd with another Veil. She runs into Gay∣love's Arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Save me, save me, save me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: What's the matter, Madam? [Aside] Now if there be a Beautiful Damsel thrown into my Arms, I must carry it strangely, for of this Informer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: He appears cold because Lisset is by. I wou'd tell you all my Misfortunes, but commit them to your self alone, none must be privy to the Story—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Now I do long to know her Condition. My Dear pretty Youth, [to Lisset] your Lady has promis'd faithfully to let me hear from her to Night, so I will suspend my Curiosity till then—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: P'shaw, now you turn me off just when I had a Mind to have told ye the whole Affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Sir, won't you listen to a distress'd Woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Gay
SP.P: Yes, yes; what shall I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Come I'll tell you what you shall do; put me into your Apartment, and I'll stay till the Conference is over.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: With all my Heart; this is, you see, an Act of Cha∣rity forc'd upon me, none of my own seeking; there's sweet Meats within to piddle upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Very well, make hake hast.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Now Madam, how can I assist you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Oh very easily; my Fright was only Counterfeit. I am not pursu'd, but come in Quest of a Heart, young Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: A Heart Madam! Bless me, who has stole the pre∣cious thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Even just such another leering Rogue as your self—He wears a lac'd Coat, a light Wig, Diamond Buckles, has a certain Jene Scay in his Mein, and Fire in his Eyes, and Elo∣quence on his Tongue—in fine, I believe you are the Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Impossible Madam, by your Description—But shall I crave to view the Conquest this happy Youth has made—and Die with Envy?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Not my Face, I have sworn to the contrary; there's my Hand to convince you I am Flesh and Blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: White, and Soft, and Sweet. Loaded with Jewels, it must be a Woman of Quality.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Hold, hold, you don't intend to devour it I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: O my Conscience, I cou'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Ah, now I think on't, I am undone—for I have watch'd ye ever since you came to Madrid; you are ingag'd—a Donna at St. Dominicks claims ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: True, she has my absent Heart—but I have always a present one for a fair Lady, take that, and my Per∣son into the Bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Ah you little Virago, you'll stifle me.

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.P: Sir, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: His't, what now?

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.P: My Lady, the Lady you saw at the Chappel to Day—says, if you don't come to her this very Mi∣nute, you'll never see her more.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Umph, this 'tis to have so much Business upon one's Hands—I can't forsake her I have seen, and know to be Handsome, for one I only guess to be so—Besides, this is so fond she'll follow me agen—stay a Moment I will go.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Well, what now—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Alas Madam, my dearest Friend it seems, is wound∣ed in a Quarrel—I must fly to him—but beg to know where I may wait upon your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: If I lose this Golden Opportunity, I must ne'er ex∣pect another.

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.P: If you disoblige my Lady, she's of a Humour too Haughty to forgive.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: What is it a Woman then—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Hush you little Fool—'twas about a Woman he says my Friend was Hurt, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.P: If you have any Honour, go.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: If you have either Love or Pity, stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Gad, Madam, I know not what to resolve on; take you this Arm—and Urchin take this, and fairly divide me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: That's frankly offer'd truly—no, you shall see how generous I'll be; go—let me into your Lodging, and I'll patiently wait your coming back.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: That's very kind upon my Life—but Madam, you forget the Youth's here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: That's nothing, he knows me not—be you swift in your Return.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: to be sure. [locks her in] lead on.

DIV3.L: Thus thro' the happy Realms of Bliss I rove,
VVhilst bright contending Beauties offer Love.
DIV3.TRAILER: The End of the second Act.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: WHY you confound me with what you tell me; first a Lady throws her self into your Arms, you say—you never see her Face—but lock her up with our Damosels Mercury in your own Lodgings—then follow a little Foot Page from Church to Church, till he drops you in a crowd, and you surpriz'd and amaz'd, know not what to make of the Adventure.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: 'Tis very true Bellmour—I am a Puppy—these Spanish VVomen make a meer Ass of me; however I have one fast under this Key, and she shall pay for all.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: But what account do you think your Ganemede, as you call him, will give of you to your Fair unknown?

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Oh he's a VVitness I am Innocent, and can't accuse me—besides, at present I am very angry, for the young Rogue my Guide, must lead me that ridiculous Dance by her Directions.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Come let's enter—then compel one Female at least, to discover who she is, before we part with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ay that we will—and I'll send a Rattle by Ganemede.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to Gaylove's Apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Madam, Madam, where are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Sir, Sir, here's no Body.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: No! They can't get into the Closet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: No Mortal, by Jupiter Ammon.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: VVitchcraft, sheer VVitchcraft.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: See Tablets open, and newly writ on.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Give them me.

DIV3.P: Go ye false Loon, with your present Heart, and your absent Heart; What have ye no Instinct about you? (so) I suppose your Comrade is just such another, and my Friend like me, Vnfortunate in an unconstant Spark.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Do you hear that?

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Ay, 'tis my hard Fate to keep Company with such a Rogue. See how Dangerous it is to pin one's Reputation on another Man's Sleeve.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Stay, stay, hear it out.

DIV3.P: You must confess you deserve no Favour; however rest satis∣fied, we'll keep our Words at the Church, and see you this Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Oh dull Dog as I was! And did another Veil deceive me? Cou'd it be the same VVoman—Nay, I thought the Tone of the Voice was alike, and fancy'd all Spanish VVo∣men spoke with the same Key.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: The Tone of the Voice! But pry'thee what's become of them? there's the greatest VVonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Hold, hold, here's more in another Hand.

DIV3.P: I, like a Mouse, have been nibling your Sweet-smeats, and now am crept into my Hole,

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: I am sure I have search'd every Hole; there's no place but this VVindow, and that must break both their Necks, unless they were Cats.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Pough, they are Cunning here in Spain, and carry Ladders of Silken Ropes about with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: You may as well say they carry Wings—but there's no finding it out, and so we must be content.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ha, here comes Grave Don Philip, and my discreet Sister, we'll withdraw and talk further of this Matter, be sure let's keep the House to night in expectation of a Summons.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Agreed.—

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Your Story is very surprising, and you have all the Reason and Justice in the World on your side; I will dispose my Ant the Ambassodress, to receive the distress'd Lady with all that Civility and Candour which is so natural to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: My only Aim is to get my Sister into my Power before I attempt any thing by Law, knowing Gomez so de∣sperate, her Life may else be in Danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: You cannot be too Cautious, when you have to deal with a Man of such wicked Principles.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Here comes a faithful Servant, who assists me in all my just Designs.

DIV3.P: Well, trusty Pedro, have you order'd things so, that this Night's Adventure may be feasible, speak freely before this Lady, for she is so Good to be of the Party.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SP.P: I have done my best, my Lord, and hope to let your Friends in at the Garden Gate, and take her out of that Apartment that joyns this House, and where of late she and her Companion always is.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Are we so near Neighbours then?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Yes Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SP.P:
But Sir, I would beg a Letter from you, least she refuse to go with me, I shall have no Time to tell her the
Design—and she has too much Reason to mistrust Plots from the old Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: That I had consider'd, and here's one ready for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro.
Em.
SP.P: Providence will certainly prevent such Barbarity, and prosper your good Intentions.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Pedro farewel—as soon as it is dark I'll send the Men I promis'd, and when my Orphan injur'd Sister's Safe, you shall name your own Reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro.
SP.P: I meet with it if I preserve the Children of my good old Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Honest Creature—I see my Brother coming; I am sure both he and Bellmour are at your Service if you want their Aid.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Madam, I wou'd not hazard them in Dangers, since for my Money I can with Ease procure those who understand the Country better, and will gladly undertake the Business.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: You have Reason I am convinc'd, and will not mention it to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Luckily encounter'd—Sister of late you complain of my Neglect, now I have brought you some Musick.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: That's kind indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Yes to my self; for being ingag'd to wait for a Message from my dear invisible, this will passe le Temps, and prevent Inquiries and Reprimands.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: But my dear Brother, I have a World to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ay my dear Sister after the Song; but they cannot stay, they perform at Court to Night I assure ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: 'Tis your Danger troubles me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Fear nothing—fear nothing—Thrummers will you never begin?

DIV3.STAGE: A Dialogue design'd for Mrs. Willis, Mr. Pack and Mrs. Perin. Mrs. Willis sings like a very old Woman, Mrs. Perin her Gran∣daughter, and Mr. Pack a spruce young Fellow.
Old Woman following her Grandaughter in.
DIV3.L: Why hunnow Hussy, How dare you leave your Spinning?
The Slut minds nothing but gadding abroad;
If thus you make such a bad beginning,
Ye Baggage, and take such an idle Road,
Ye shall ne're be Dame of my Oxon and Cows,
My Lands and my Dairy, and all my Wheat Mows.

SP.SPEAKER: Girl.
SP.L: Marry gap forsooth Grannum, your Anger I know;
Your are in love with our Rafe, who is lately turn'd Beau,
A Husband much fitter for me, I trow,
For all you bridle your shaking Head,
You know you cannot lye straight in your Bed,
Yet you, good Lack, have a Mind to Wed.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Woman.
SP.L: Hold your Tongue, or say what you can,
Oh he's a Sweet, Oh he's a kind young Man.
Get you in ye sawcy Quean;
I'll give ye ne're a Groat if you are seen.

SP.SPEAKER: Rafe Sings.
SP.L: Oh how she bridles and sets off her self;
What will we not do for darling Pelf?
Ene take an old Ken and hug in our Arms,
And talk to the Hag of Passion and Charms.
To her] My Honey, my Love, my Joy, my Delight,
Now tell me the Day, now tell me the Night
When we shall be Happy, when we shall be Wed,
To keep thee warm up, and warmer a Bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Woman.
SP.L: Ah what sweet Words, what soft Looks are these,
How Easie, how Easie a young Man can please;
Shou'd I consent, your Flames might grow cold,
I doubt I am a little, a little too Old.

SP.SPEAKER: Rafe.
SP.L: No, no, no, no.
Thy Lips are two Cherries, thy Eyes are two Stars,
Then Widow prepare for amorous Wars;
Thou art all Love and all Truth
I am all Vigour and Youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Girl Peeping.
SP.L: She has indeed left a merry Colt's Tooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Rafe.
SP.L: Then Widdow prepare for amorous Wars;
I'll kiss thee and hug thee, and kindle Love's Fire,
Thou full of Delight, I full of Desire.
Then Widow, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Woman.
SP.L: Hold off your Kisses, I pray now forbear,
You want but my Money, I'll make you my Heir;
Shou'd I consent your Flames might grow cold,
I doubt I am a little, a little too Old.

SP.SPEAKER: Rafe.
SP.L: Your Wealth I despise, and all your Rich Store,
'Tis you my Dear Goddess, tis you I adore.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Woman.
SP.L: Oh how he loves me, his Flames will never grow Cold.
His Truth has convinced me I am not too old.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: This is very Gallant I acknowledge, but truly Bro∣ther I must take a time to tell you the Reports.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Emilia I'll come and hearken to you with profound Attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: When.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: When I can find nothing else to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Ye provoking thing you, if I did not love you what need I care—at present I am ingaged in an Affair for this Gentleman I hope to serve him.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: You are all goodness, nor can I express my acknow∣ledgements.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
Em.
SP.P: You ridicule my Fears; but be not too venturous, that's all I ask.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: No, no, farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Your Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: My Dear Bellmour, any News?

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Not yet, I have been walking this Hour in the Cloy∣ster —Expectation is a terrible uneasy Torment.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ay when a Man expects to have his Bones broke. Worthy Gentlemen, my very Honoured Masters leave me out at this Night's Adventure—I am sure 'twill thrive the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Peace Raskal, and do not provoke a Man already in a Fret.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Jo—ah wer't thou capable—dids't thou con∣ceive the mighty Power of Love all Dangers would be Tri∣fles, Pleasures—to Possess the Dear Object.—

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Now I have found it out, 'tis the Danger makes it the Dear Object to you Sir—how many sweet Billets∣doux have you had from Mrs. Fond-Love the finest La∣dy that ever trod the Mall, and clapt them into your Pocket unopen'd—flung into your Coach and drove like the De∣vil to a Woman that us'd you ill?

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
