SP.P: This Rogue will set up for Wit, and not be content to be beat for it, Sirrah 'twas to peruse them at more Leisure.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Nay, I am sure I have often had 'em untouched, to light the Lamp for your Tea and the pretty Seal, which was a Cupid in Flames, has been Sacrific'd in Spirits of Wine and yet she writ so sweetly, as I said they made my Mouth Water, for I always sav'd a bit of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Do ye hear Bellmour, this Dog has a taste of Amour —if he wou'd but encourage it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell
SP.P: Hang him Scoundrel, I believe if once he had suffer∣ed thoroughly, 'twould reconcile him to the Cause—as Spaniels must be chastis'd before they learn their Tricks.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Thankee Dear Sir, a good Drubbing wou'd rather cure me from ever running at Mutton agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: But why do I waste my Breath with him, which shou'd be employed in Prayers for an auspicious Moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: How! I did not Imagine your Case had been so desperate.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Oh, I am in Love to Destraction.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: In troth, in my Mind you are both a little distracted.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Look out sharp Sirrah, do you spy no Messenger?

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P:
Yes, yes, talk of the Devil and his Imps appear,
here's my Governour and a Smock'd Fac'd Boy, I hope now I may be spar'd?

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Gusman, followed at a Distance by Lisset.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Don.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Meaning me.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Yes, your Ear,

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Here again my Spirit, my Aerial—I had best lay hold on you lest you vanish.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Hush till they have done, I wou'd not be seen by Gusman.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Art thou sure it is the same?

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Most certain, has she not a crooked Blind old Hus∣band.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Infallible Signs, conduct me quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: There waits a Coach at the Door, but you must ask no Questions, take your Man with you, because I wou'd not approach the House.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: A Lard, a Lard, I warrant there's a Blunderbluss be∣tween every Brick,

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Leave Roaring and come along Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: What will the cautious Bellmour? go I know not where, he that cou'd advise.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: You see how much easier it is to give good Counsel than to follow it—Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Success attend ye; I am upon the Point of inga∣ging too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Come Guide.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Let me speak one Word to that Youth, and I am for you—pray Sir, do you belong to the House of Don Gomez?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Have you never heard them speak of a fair Damsl called Lisset?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Yes often, but the Poor Creature's in Prison during Life, they say Gomez is inexorable.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Ha, the Ladies promised me her Release, or I'd no have undertook their Business—well I'll be in Prison e'er Morning, I am resolved.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: No, no, take Day Light along with you, I beseech ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Gentlemen do but observe how these two Consult —Pray mind them, if we don't all three come Home with our Throats cut, I'll be hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha, well said Jo.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: No I am fixed—Come Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: But I shall watch ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Allons Jo.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Jo—ay, I follow with as good a Will, as a Bear to the Stake, or a Thief to the Gallows, I can tell ye that.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: In the first Place let me beg to know how you got out of these Lodgings; if you can rise and fall like the Spirits in an Opera—or have Wires, or Wings, or what con∣veyance, pray confess?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: 'Tis the only Secret I am obliged not to tell ye, if I ingage to make you happy with a fine Woman of great Birth, and great Fortune, and a great deal of Sense.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Hold, hold, enough of all Conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Sure you may defer your Curiosity, and if you ob∣tain the end, be content a while to continue Ignorant of the Means.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Very true—well then my pretty Privateer whi∣ther am I to be conducted.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: To the Land of Promise, to see and talk with your Mistress freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Kindly said, I'faith; come let's begin our Journey then.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Stay, stay, you must enter into some Conditions first.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: What are they Quick, quick, my Word, my Honour and all that—I am in hast.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Look ye, the Lady you adore resolves to be very kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Good!

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: But very cautious and therefore if you shou'd not a∣gree upon Preliminaries, you are never to know with whom you treated.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: On the Affairs of Love begin quite different from those of War, we yield to all Conditions before the Engagement, but alike, for when we have taken the Town we sel∣dom keep them.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: A frank Confession.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Nay, Child I am always sincere—but to your Proposals.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: They are these, assoon as you come into the Coach you must consent to let me blind your Eyes with this Hand∣kerchief, that you may not see the very Light 'till you come to her Apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Withal my Heart. Blind as the God of Love, I'll steal upon my Blessing nor cove Light 'till her fair Eyes in∣spire. Where there is so much Beauty, I'll not suspect de∣ceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Upon my Life you shall be safe and happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Come then.

DIV3.L: For Love we venture as for Darling Fame,
Tho' Different Ways yet still the end's the same
And who sets forth in each must throw off Fear,
'Tis glorious Hazard makes the Blessing Dear.
DIV3.STAGE: Scene changes to the Garden-House. Enter Clarinda Laura and Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Well I'll swear my Heart Beats and Akes, now this Interview is so near; just like a raw Soldier at the first Onset.

SP.SPEAKER: Lua.
SP.P: Oh 'tis a Sign you'll be the more Couragious when your Hands in—but what have you to fear—that only Party thro' a Window and consult about your Escape Poor I venture upon a wild Young Fellow into my Apartment—Beatrice be near me, stir not an Inch e.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: I warrant ye Madam I'll give him no Opportunity —and they say there's never no Mischief done if a Seducer's Opportunity be wanting.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Suppose the old Man.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Suppose the Sky shou'd fall—your raising Scru∣ples brings them upon us; has not Trusty Liscias drawn up a Scheme how they Govern Women in Turky and is not the Credulous Fool altering it with a wise Design to show it to the King and Counsel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Ay but.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Agen at your But's? be more resolute or I'll leave you out of the Plot and run away by my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: You wou'd not be so barbarous—yet believe me Laura, did I dare tell even Thee my Story, you would not blame my Fears, I had a Brother once; his untimely Fate may Warn me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: What is the Monster then a Murderer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: I must be a little longer Silent—but if I escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: We shall know all—get you gone then.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Now for the Window;—Providence protect us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Young Men deliver us I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Amen to that sweet Prayer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Well said Beatrice, she must fly too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: I hope so Ladies; by my Consent, there shou'd be nothing in Petticoats left near Gomez.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Farewel; when shall we meet again?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: In perfect Liberty I hope—with a Redress for all our Grievances.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: I hope so too; but my Forebodying Heart, forbids it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Courage! Come Beatrice let's into the farther Room, the Spies on our Party, are all watching the Enemies Motion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Yes Madam.

DIV3.STAGE: Scene, the Piazza of the House. Enter Gomez with a Letter in his Hand, followed by two or three Servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Ye sneaking Curs, ye hired Scoundrels, you knew nothing of this—these Plots and Contrivances, ha—Unhappy Gomez, I have not one that I can trust—od∣so —and had not my own Wisdom, mistrusted that Dog Pedro, for going in and out so often to Day, I had been un∣done —here's Machinations against me, here's a Hel∣lish Design, let every one of my Servants be Arm'd, and Guard each Avenue—is Pedro bound, and thrown into the Dungeon?
Servant. He is my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: The Rogue would have Eat the Letter, when I had him search'd, the Villain tore part with his Teeth and Name, a Damnable Plotter I warrant him; odso, are the Women safe under Lock and Key?
Servant. They are.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Where's Liscias?
Servant. I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: You don't know! Seek him Dunce, Loggerhead, he only is Crafty and Cruel, I want his Aid, odso, Guard you this Door whilst I find Clarinda, and use her, as her vile Deeds deserve—be careful Slaves, or your Lives shall answer it; be vigilant I say—odso, there's Danger stir∣ring.
Servant. We must Guard the Doors on the inside, I suppose, come lets follow him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P:
I find I am a perfect Woman, nay the most fear∣ful of my Sex, when alone, I want Laura's Spirit, now I fancy a Thousand Dangers and dread the greatest—if
I should meet that leads to the Win∣dow, if he shou'd catch me going towards the Street.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Oh thou Daughter of Eniquity (she starts) thou Direct Spawn of the Serpent, thou Viper hatch'd from the Egg of a Cockatrice; odso, thou Dalilah the second.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Take breath Old Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Confidence! art thou not ashamed ha! art thou not startl'd at thy black Guilt ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: I will bear up if I can. (Aside) Guilt! what Guilt? indeed it is a sort of Guilt, to fear, to value Life more than it deserves, and yield my self a Slave to thy Tyran∣ny; of any other Crime, I am Innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Innocent! oh steel, and Brass, and Copper, weak weak Similie's odso! you have this Night then no vile Treacherous Plot upon my Honour: ha! no damn'd Contrivance to Escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: If I have, it is not vile—nor is your Honour mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Haughty my Minx—odso—I shall humble ye have you forgot this Dagger, or my solemn Oath.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: No I remember both; spare my Youth, see how I tremble, I will submit, indeed I will—oh spare me on my Knees, I beg you.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Confess then, from whom this fatal Scrowl—who it is that frees you this Night? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Me?

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Yes you? who sent this Letter, writ in Hell, odso—Confess I say. He'll send Arm'd Men it seems to force you from a Villains Gripe, so the Monster calls me. Ha! who is ?

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: It can't be Bellmour—I am happier than I thought.

DIV3.P: By all my sorrows and my sufferings, I never heard of be∣fore—have I then a Powerful Deliverer?

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Ha! by the Puport of the Letter she may not know have gone too far odso.
Do ye rejoyce Strumpet? ha Fool, thou hast no Friends, thou hast, thou dyest.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Indeed, indeed I have none.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Nay, my Servants are all alarm'd, and Death odso will surely meet each bold approacher.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Unhappy Bellmour! Why want I courage to dye first.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Ha what's that you murter, why are you praing here alone, why towards the Street, Answer me, that my servants are all Villains, but now I will my self-immure Thee—and with to Morrow's Light, thou shalt leave Spain, and boast of no more upholders, odso thy Stubborness shall Yield i shall so—come on or I will drag ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: I do yield—trample on me, use me if possible yet worse, yet save him—Pity his Rashness oh save him.—

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Him what him—conclude him Dead—con∣clude him and if you Struggle another Moment—odso I will begin with you—what, hoa Liscias, resistance is in vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Help, Murder, Murder.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Bellmour, Gusman and Jo with a Dark Lantho

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Oh good Sir, for the Lord's Sake go back—upon my Life I saw by the Shadow of the Moon, Amd Men and eard the cry of Murder—just then when you bid me scout out as you call'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Your own Fancy Fool, you saw Arms, as you did Moonshine, when there is no Moon; as for your Ears they are thick they han't been lugg'd a good while.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Well, I am like the Woman in the Ballad of Troy Town▪ I always speak Truth, but am never believed.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Now I wou'd go where that Cry of Murder is, for my Desire is a Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Oh wretched Jo, was ever Mortal that lov'd his own Person as thou dost condemn'd to follow two Madmen —

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Peace Coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ah wou'd but that Name preserve me, I should love it as long as I lived.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Are we near the Window Gusman.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Just under it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Give the Sign then.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Hem! hem! hem! no answer Sirrah, do you hem, your Lungs are stronger than mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ah catch me at that Sport—I hem! I'll hang assoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Raskal! I'll make you roar out as you us'd to do when the Watch pursu'd you in Covent-garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ah wou'd I were there now, knock'd down by one of their Staves of Authority, I am sure 'tis less danger than be∣ing here.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Hem Scoundrel!

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Hem! hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: See the Rogue has a Noise without doubt.

DIV3.STAGE: Gomez, and several Servants, burst out at the Door, Arm'd with Pistols.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: I have don't indeed, fly, fly, Murder, Murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: 'Tis time truly. (they Retreat, Gomez pursues, they fire at one another. (falls down.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: I am slain, I am kill'd, I am wounded.

DIV3.STAGE: A Servant enters hastily, and speaks to Gomez.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My Lord, my Lord, we are beset in the Garden, by twice this Number.

SP.SPEAKER: Gom.
SP.P: Thither, thither then, and Bar the Doors, I hope some of these are maul'd.

DIV3.STAGE: [They go out, and fasten the Doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: They have mis'd us Gusman, but this fearful Wretch is hurt, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Oh, oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Where's your Wound.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I thought as much.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Oh, oh, yet I feel my self Heart whole methinks, but I am sure, I have lost a Leg or an Arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Hast thou poor Fellow? Why then you must e'en lie here 'till we can send a Surgeon, and I fear the Enemy will return.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Will they so—no, no, I'll go to the Sur∣geon then my self,—I thank ye Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: The Rogue's unhurt the English Proverb has preser∣ved him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: No his own Conduct secured him, gad I have Cun∣ning enough to be a General, if I had but a little Courage, but for Heaven's Sake, now let's be gone, think Sir the Pitch∣er, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Impertinence—Gusman whats next to be done, I wou'd not willingly suspect the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: I warrant her a Gilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I'll Pawn my Life she knows nothing of it, retire to your Lodgings—the Coach waits, and will conduct you safely back, the Alquisal is coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Dear, dear Sir, let us be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: I'll take your Counsel.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: The first that was good you ever followed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: For tho' I love my Mistress well—the Ventures too great to loose, and my Life into the Bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ah 'tis a damn'd Lottery, when Death may come in∣stead of a Prize—will you go Sir, I shall be unmanner∣ly else, and lead the Way.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Sure Jo you'll stay with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Say you so. Gad I'll try my Heels first.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: How the Rogue Scours—where is this Coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Here at the Door Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: You'll be sure to send.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I will. [goes with him, and returns.] Now for my Purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Stand.—

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I intend it.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: What are you, and what was the Uproar▪ just be∣fore the Door of Gomez.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I kill'd a Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Why you must to Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: That is my desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: And be hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: Uh!

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: Pough a Madman▪ let's not trouble the Corrigidore with him, all's quiet now.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: What will ye not take me to Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Ah Poor Man go Home and Sleep—come, come to our Rounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.L: It is impossible to compass my Design.
Lisset I wou'd thy Fellow Prisoner he
But the same Fate which others shun Flies me.

DIV3.STAGE: Scene, the Garden-House Apartment. Enter Laura and Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I wonder they are not come—how cruel is this Delay.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Ay your Minds employed upon a Handsome young Man and you won't listen to me, but I am sure I have heard terrible Noises, about the palace on every side.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: P'shaw the Wench is a Fool fear always deceives both the Ears and the Eyes 'tis fear only has made all the Hobgoblins since Adam.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: If you had seen what I have seen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: eace they Come.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lisset with Gay-Love with a Handkerchief ty'd over his Eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Madam I have brought him Hoodwink'd like a Hawk, and now at once, I let him loose upon his Prey.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ay Faith Madam—my little Ganemede has whisk∣ed me up and down the Lord knows where, in the Dark, but landing me here, I forgive the Fatigue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis a Mad Rogue that's the Truth on't, and had not Breeches secur'd her, I shou'd scarce have ventur'd her with you

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: A Woman, Gad I mistrusted it, she was so pert, and so pretty—Woe had been unto ye, if I had known it, when we were at Blind-mans Buff together just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Fear him not Madam, your mighty Threatners sel∣dom prove so terrible.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Malice—well my Dear invinsible, let us now come to an Enclarissment, give me to know, to whom I have Mortgaged my Heart, for the Possession of that fair Tene∣ment, and what my hopes must depend on.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: How assur'd the little false Villain is, why have you forgot the violent Love you made to the Donna in distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: No, no, I remember it full well, and thought I had lock'd her up too—but how she escaped, indeed is past my Understanding—and for that Affair your self can Wit∣ness I left you to seek ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Um—you thought you had secur'd me, tho' —however the utmost Limits of that Time I can call my own, drawing near, I resolve to make a full discovery, Opportunities being precious in our Country—know then I am Sister to a Man of Quality—who is severe and positive—my Fortunes are very considerable and ought to be freely at my Command; but this Brother of mine assu∣ming a Tyrannick Power, Condemns me and my Estate to an Old, Horrid, Abominable, Intollerable Fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: A most intollerable Case I am sure—come to my Arms, my Fair, where I for ever will secure thee from these Impending Dangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Not so fast my Mercurial Friend—Yes your Arms are always open to receive the distress'd. I'll say that for ye—hear me out, now 'tis in the Ambassadors Power to defend me from my Brother's Authority, till my case is heard—Lisset who passes for an Eunuch, and by that means has great Credit with the old Man, can let us out by the Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ay or Conjure us out, I suppose 'tis all one with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Whilst your Friend Bellmour conducts the other way, Clarinda who has also great Complaints to make.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: You shall surely find both Justice and Redress, nor will I doubt yours to remember your Deliverers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I never was Ungrateful—but tell me sincerely do the Wives in England pass their Days so deliciously as Fame reports, do they go where, and when they please without giving their Husbands any account of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Account! Oh fie, 'tis the worst bred thing in the World on either side, to examine. They play Masquerade, Dance, in fine, possess all Diversions without Interruption or Controul

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Oh sweet England—I don't wonder at your La∣dyship for chusing a Cavalier of that Country to give you Freedom, for here if you had changed your old Spaniard for a young, the Confinement had been the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Come dear Madam, let the Terrour of the Old Man hasten your Flight, I long till I have you in safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I run a strange Risque—but my case is desperate Lisset lead the Way; Beatrice follow close.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Your Hand my fair Adventurer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Bless me, what noise is that.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Heavens! Gomez and half a Dozen Russians Arm'd with Swords and Pistols.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ha, then I am betrayed, oh faithless Woman, but I will ell my Life and dearly too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Oh Hold!

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Off Madam there's no jesting now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau
SP.P: You think me base and the appearance is against me, yet by all that's good, I swear I am Innocent, if I you have any regard for me or Truth, this way fly your Sword is vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Oh Madam they come!

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Hold the Door a Moment—pray this way Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Perhaps to greater Dangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Upon my Soul, you will be safe, do but step up and go along between the Rafters.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Supposing this is true, I leave you to suffer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I can escape, indeed I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Nay, dally not, they enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: For Heaven's Sake Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Farewel, I do, I know not what.

DIV3.STAGE: [He seems to get up, going out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: He's gone, and all good Stars protect him.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Gomez and Servants Arm'd. So what Capricio—now to disturb my Peace, and wrac me with your unreasonable Jelousies.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Ah Liscias art thou there—I am undone Liscias, the House is beset all round, and they say a Young Man came out of the Garden into this Apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Only the Shadow of a Man, upon my Word my Lord; 'twas I.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Was it indeed—alas I'me at my Wits End, go secure Laura with Clarinda—guard them as you wou'd your Lives—for if they stir you dye, odso.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: What new piece of Matchless Tyranny is this, my Brother cou'd not sure design I shou'd be us'd thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: I'll answer it to her Brother—away with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Villain, Monster—

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: My Noble Lord—may I inquire how you are threatned and what the danger is, that thus alarms ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Liscias all my Affairs go wrong—I fear a Ne∣phew is returned whom I thought dead—Villainous Pedro seems to confess it—and that which adds most to my Spleen, is, sending to Prison, I find that damn'd Devil Lisset's escap'd, I am sure her Wit's employed in these con∣founded Plot against me.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Is't possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Too sure—cou'd I but catch her, this Dagger shou'd Sacrifice her immediately; first I'de rip up her Face, which she loves better than her Soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Oh Heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Tear her Flesh with burning Pincers red hot, ay red hot,—odso use Fire, Water, all the Plagues Mankind, or the Devil ever invented—you tremble Liscias.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Do I Sir, 'tis with Rage then to see you thus abu∣sed—instruct me to revenge your Wrongs, and your Foes shall Tremble.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Listen then to my designs, here I'll leave thee to guard the Women—whilst I have my Coaches made ready and will this Night meet Lauras's Brother upon the Road put her into his Hands, and force Clarinda to leave Spain with me, you'll with us Liscias.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: Most certainly, do you think I'll leave my Dear, Dear Lord, whose Inclinations suits mine exactly to punish Woman kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Ay Liscias—when I stand in fear of no Secrets being discovered—then we'll Tyrannize at pleasure; well I'll prepare for our Journey; if Clarinda resists, suppose I strangle her ha, don't they strangle disobedient Wifes in Tur∣key, ha Liscias.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: Yes my dear Lord, (Aside) oh Horrid. Heaven send me a Diliverance from thy Clutches, I say.

DIV3.HEAD: The Scene changes to Bellmour's Apartment, He sits Reading.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: What no news of Gaylove.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: None Sir, none, ah there never comes good of these Mad Attempts—'tis more Heavens Mercy, than our de∣serts, that we are safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Better a thousand such as thee was Sacrificed, than Gaylove Fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Doctors differ—I am not of your Opinion Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: My Heart akes for him—heark what noise is that.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Noile! Swords and Pistols perhaps—I dare not look out.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Gaylove, as having leap'd down.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Where am I now? I have been almost stifl'd between the Rafters—ha? a Spaniard the very Husband perhaps to my very Woman—well there's no retreating, I must stand my Ground—Don! Necessity forc'd me to in∣trude, 'twas to preserve a Life, which Nature bids me thus defend

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Heavens! what do I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Bellmour—Jo.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ay, ay, the same dear Sir, the same put up, put up.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: If I had not seen thy Fool's Face, I had been tilting at Bellmour with his grave Appearance of a Spaniard.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: How came ye hither, I am amaz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Faith so am I—here must be a communication for squeezing my self as far as I cou'd go, something gave way and I drop'd down.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: What can it mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis Art magick that's certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Coxcomb—I confess it is strange, I am sure I was a considerable time in going to the Place, and made a hun∣dred Turnings.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: So did I, both going and coming back—we must Examine into it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: No Matter, no matter—as long as we are safe what need we care how—only run your selves no more into the Snare.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: I'll find this out, tho' I ventur'd ten Thousand Lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: And I.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: With all my Heart Gentlemen—only leave poor Jo at Home, who desires to serve you in Peace and Quietness.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ha Emilia and Don Philip at this time of Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Brother I am glad to find you, and your Friend here, Don Philip begs your Assistance, to free an oppress'd Lady, from most unjust usage.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Good Madam don't draw us into more dangers, we have been endeavouring to free oppress'd Ladies all this Night—and been shot, and run through ten times, and had a Thousand Misfortunes besides.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Peace Raschal.—We shall be ambitious to serve Don Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: With our Lives and Fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Don. Phil.
SP.P: Sir I did attempt to do my self Justice, but my Force being repell'd by Force, I am obliged to desire you wou'd appear with me, the Inquisitor General is come to the Ambassadors, his Officers he has lent me, and I have now hopes my sister may be delivered.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Dear Brother help this unhappy Lady, whose Story I have heard and shall wait with Impatience till your Re∣turn, and send my Prayers along with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Dear Madam let me stay and pray too, I can pray as heartily in a fright, as e'er a blind Beggar of them all.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Pry'thee Coward stay, ill Luck attends where ever the Buzzard goes.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Ay call what you please—do but leave me behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: I'll retire and prepare every thing for your Reception.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: My whole Life must be one Acknowledgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: And mine for being left out at this Adventure.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Come Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: We attend ye.

DIV3.STAGE: Scene the Garden-House. Enter Laura, Clarinda, Lisset and Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: We are ruin'd—we must throw our selves into the Hands of Wild Young Men, or else be murdered by a cruel Old one.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: For my part I'll trust my self with all the Young Fellows in Christendom—e'er I venture my Life with a Blind old Villain of Fourscore.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: You are in the right Madam—for I have told you his Bloody purpose—he swore to strangle you, and to deliver you (to Clarinda) this Night into your Brother's Hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: That's as bad—I had as leive dye, as part with my dear Wild Englishman.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Why do ye delay then—when you may be safe—that passage Donna Laura made for her Diversi∣on, when the Ambassador's House stood so long empty, now may save your Lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: I dare not venture.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Will ye be left behind, for I will positively go.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: And I, for never poor Wretch was threatned like me.

DIV3.STAGE: A noise without—Murder, Murder, break down the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Ha, he is killing all the Servants that take our parts, away, away.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: So, so, now the greatest Coward goes first, on, on,

DIV3.STAGE: They break down the Door. Enter Don Philip, Gomez guard∣ded Gaylove, Bellmour, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Villain where's my Sister, my Orphan Sister, left to thy false Care.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Unhand me Raskals—seize a Man in his own House.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: 'Tis done by Law, Answer me, where's my Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: The Women under my care, I lock'd and barr'd in this Room.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Falsehood—here's no body.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Oh that's a common thing in Spain, I have lock'd and double lock'd my Door, with substantial Persons in my Room, and at my Return found no body.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Peace Gaylove—by this deformed Old Man the Women they are in Quest of, must be our Angels.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ay but where are they—now suppose after all they shou'd be Fairies, Zilphs, Salmanders, Fantons, Spectres.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Foolsheads—pr'y thee Peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Here's no Creature—bring him to the Inqui∣sitor General—there he shall Confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Perhaps my Honest cunning Eunuch has conveyed them out—I'll bear up. (Aside) Have me where you will—a Grandee of Spain must have Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Bring him along to the Ambassadours.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: I am Big with Expectation.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: So am I.

DIV3.STAGE: Scene Bellmour's Lodging. The Inquisitor seated, attended by Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Inqui.
SP.P: Have they taken Gomez.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: Yes my Lord, here they come.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Don Philip, Bellmour, Gaylove, Gomez guarded.

SP.SPEAKER: Inqui.
SP.P: Don Gomez you stand accused of most Notorious Crimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: My Lord Inquisitor if you but knew.—

SP.SPEAKER: Inqui.
SP.P: First hear you charge—Don Philip justify your late Impeachment.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: My Lord, this cruel Man, half Brother to my Fa∣ther was left by him Guardian to my self and Sister—me he wou'd have murdered—my Poor Sister, he most In∣cestuously has forced to Wed him.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: False all False the young Man has broke my com∣mands, and left the Indies, and now Invents this Story.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: What an old Dog's this Bellmour, and what Justice it would be to make him a Cuckold.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Right—Marry his Niece a Monster.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: This my Lord, the Inquisition reaches.

SP.SPEAKER: Inqui.
SP.P: Gomez These are horrid Crimes, what can'st thou say.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: My Lord, upon my Honour every Article is false, his Sister Clarinda is in a Monastery at Toledo, my Wife in∣deed is young and bears that Name, which I suppose cre∣ates the hot-brain'd mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Inq.
SP.P: You hear this Don Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: (Aside) I hope my dear Liscias, has secured or stab'd the Woman, no matter which.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Bring in Pedro—whom in the Dungeon my Servants found.

SP.SPEAKER: Inq.
SP.P: Know you Friend if the Lady, Don Gomez calls Wife, s Sister to this Lord, and his own Neice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ped.
SP.P: My Lord she is, I have serv'd them from their In∣fancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Hear me my Lord Inquisitor—this Servant is a Hired Ruffian—must one who wears these Robes born Noble, be thus betray'd by pejur'd Servants and wild Debau∣chees.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: So now I have found Justice sitting in state, sure I shall compass my design. My Lords and Gentlemen, I am the Man that has been the Abettor Contriver and head ma∣ker of all these Plots.

SP.SPEAKER: Inq.
SP.P: What Fellow's this.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Is not this our Pimp in Ordinary.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: The same—he is a little Craz'd too; really the People are all mad in Spain.

SP.SPEAKER: Inq.
SP.P: What can'st thou say.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus
SP.P: My Lord I can say a great deal—but I desire first, to be sent to Prison, and then let me be examined.

SP.SPEAKER: Inq.
SP.P: Take him back, he's a Fool or a Madman.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: Bear back, bear back.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I won't bear back—can't you send me to Pri∣son, for Contempt of the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.P: Silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Inq.
SP.P: Gomez since thou objects against the Evidence, pro∣duce thy Wife, and that will end the Matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: I cannot well my Lord, she is secur'd at present, a∣gainst their Violence.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: The Archbishop of Toledo knows the Matter, he is in Madrid.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: That touches Home. (Aside) My Lord defer it but 'till to Morrow I will give you Satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil
SP.P: Let him bring forth my Sister, good my Lord.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Emilia, Clarinda, Laura vail'd, Lisset, Beatrice and Jo.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: (catching hold of Philip) My Dearest Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: My only Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Give me a part I pray, I am sure I have ventur'd my Life for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: And I also.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ah, ha my fair invisible—now I have caught this Hand agn in my Territories, we sink or swim toge∣ther, rise or fall for upon Honour we part no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Hold fast then—'tis soft and slippery.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: 'Tis time for me to get off, odso.

SP.SPEAKER: Inq.
SP.P: Secure Gomez—is this your Sister Don Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: My Lord she is, and let her now declare her Usage.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Safe in this Presence, I'll unfold a Tale will strike ye with amazement, that Old Wretch—whom I shou'd reverence, but for his deeds—came to me, and with a lift up dagger swore if I wou'd not consent to be his Bride, that Moment was my last. Your Brother said he with a Malicious Smile shall never Plague me more—Report confirm'd his Death, the Terrour of my own made me con∣sent.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: What dist thou then consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Ah I'me in an cold Sweat agen Gaylove.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Listen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Yes, I yielded to pass for his Wife, and give my For∣tunes up.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: Oh ho, to pass for his Wife only.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: His designs were to leave Spain—then I suppose I cou'd have made no more Conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Inq.
SP.P: Barbarous Man what canst thou plead.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Nothing—I am ruined past Redemption; odso!

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: That thou art indeed, odso!

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Liscias, Traytor, Eunuch, how came these Women here.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Stand by me, stand by me now, and I will tell him who I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: I warrant thee no Danger, speak boldly.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: I am not Liscias Don, nor an Eunuch Don, but an Arrant Damsel Don, and your Quondam injured Maid Lisset, odso!

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Oh Confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: What my Lisset?

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Yes your Lisset that you have kept such a Pother, a∣bout fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Inq.
SP.P: What other Ladies that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Hold not a step without me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: My Lord, my Fortunes large, and at my own dis∣posal yet by the Instigation of that old Man, my Brother, Don Lewis has plaid the Tyrant with me beyond a Mortals Patience—thus us'd I have cast my self, under the Am∣bassadour's Protection 'till I obtain Relief.

SP.SPEAKER: Inq.
SP.P: Madam you have done well—Don Gomez you must with me, and give a strict Account to my Brethren of the Inquisition for all these Enormous Crimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: Thus my ill gotten Wealth must be restored, and Cur∣ses ollow it wheresoer'e it Lights.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Ay, ay, no matter for that Old Drybones, now we are rid of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Oh happy Hours—now tell us, which way you came and let the Riddle cease. (Exit Inquisitor, Officers and Gomez.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: That I must do—as I was sitting in Care for your bold Enterprise—these Ladies enter'd, equally surprised we seem'd, till after some eager Questions I found them the Ladies you had undertook to free.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Ay but Sister how did you find them, did they fly in at the Window down the Chimney between the Rafters or how.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: I'll satisfy you old Impatience—thro' the very Passage you came, which I having an Ingenious Fellow that attended me when the House was empty, contriv'd, so that the Wainscoat opens and shuts without the least Discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: And thus you have played your Tricks and over∣heard all our Secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Yea verily; and tho' you were hurried up and down in truth the Houses joyn, and the Piazza is the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Well well, you have been so often in my Bed Cham∣ber that after a little Church Ceremony I shall certainly claim you for a Bedfellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Hold hold, you are quite to begin a new, Young Man, and all these Frollicks are to pass for a Dream.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Nay it has been a little Vissionary I confess; but in Love and War we never lose the least Advantage, nor cease till we come to an absolute Conquest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: Look how our Grave Friends are proceeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: (to Bell.) What you say is so honourable, that I am ure I shall encourage it—my self having no other Aim han the happiness of being allied to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Time must bring these things to pass, the Ambass∣dress is prepared to receive the Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: I can never sufficiently praise Heaven and you, for ny Deliverance.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: If you are kind the happiness is mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: What says Lisset? To her we are obliged for these Delights.

SP.SPEAKER: Liss.
SP.P: Faith Madam, I am in a high dispute with Gusman, I tell him I have gotten such a smack of Liberty, and such a Taste of wearing the Breeches, I shall never make a good Spanish Wife nor indure to be locked up.

SP.SPEAKER: Gus.
SP.P: I am content to run the Risque of that and I think in Justice, I deserve you fair Maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
Jo.
SP.P: What are you all joyning Pellmell, methinks now my frights are over, my Appetite's a little up, here stands a Mi∣stress prim behind, mighthap she may like (to Beatrice) my proper Person; what say you forsooth, I'll tell you what you must trust to—I have a Serving Man's Portion do you see, who for many Years of Slavery can easily give you the Sum total of his Fortunes. Item a Silver Watch, two Gold Rings about three Guineas before Hand, and as many suits of Apparel.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: So you'd have me put my stock to this fair Invento∣ry; which will scarce hold the Year round to keep that sleek Face of yours in idleness and good Eating—then I must be left with my Arms full of Squaling misery, either to keep you or be kept my self by the Parish.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: Nay if you are so short, Iha done, I am soon snub'd, do you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Bell.
SP.P: No, no it must be St. Valentines Day and all must pair

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Jo. shall be provided for.

SP.SPEAKER: Lau.
SP.P: And Beatrice if they can agree.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Thank your Honour, we'll consider on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.P: That we will for I like that Squaling misery no m than your self—I tell you that.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Brother, is the Musick gone, you had just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Gay,
SP.P: I believe not.

SP.SPEAKER: Em.
SP.P: Pray let us entertain the Ladies after their Frights▪

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: With all my Heart—Jo call in the Musick.

DIV3.HEAD: Song and Dance.
DIV3.L: Thus our Adventures end in perfect Joy
And Vertue shall my future Thoughts Employ.
You the Sole Mistress of my Heart shall Reign,
And more than Freedom, I will love my Chain.

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: All are fixed—I am sure that pleases me,
I hope from Danger, honest Jo is free.
Had fighting Sparks my Mind, all Wars wou'd cease▪
And the whole World like me, grow Fat in Peace.
